review.title: Why Do Urban Legends Go Viral?
review.abstract: Urban legends are a genre of modern folklore, consisting of stories about rare and exceptional events, just plausible enough to be believed, which tend to propagate inexorably across communities. In our view, while urban legends represent a form of "sticky" deceptive text, they are marked by a tension between the credible and incredible. They should be credible like a news article and incredible like a fairy tale to go viral. In particular we will focus on the idea that urban legends should mimic the details of news (who, where, when) to be credible, while they should be emotional and readable like a fairy tale to be catchy and memorable. Using NLP tools we will provide a quantitative analysis of these prototypical characteristics. We also lay out some machine learning experiments showing that it is possible to recognize an urban legend using just these simple features.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 1.06 081v 1 [cs.C L] 22 Jan 20Urban legends are a genre of modern folklore consisting of stories about rare and extraordinary events that are just plausible enough to be believed and that tend to spread inexorably in communities. While urban legends, in our view, are a form of "sticky" deceptive text, they are characterized by a tension between believable and unbelievable, they should be believable like a news article and unbelievable like a fairy tale to go viral. Specifically, we will focus on the idea that urban legends should mimic the details of news (who, where, when) in order to be believable, while they should be emotionally and legibly memorable like a fairy tale. With NLP tools, we will provide a quantitative analysis of these prototypical features. We will also present some machine learning experiments that show that it is possible to recognize a simple urban legend based on this very specific characteristic.

sections.heading: 3. Datasets
sections.text: To explore the characteristics of urban legends and understand the effectiveness of our ideas, we have compiled a specific dataset composed of approximately 8,000 text examples: 2,518 Urban Legends (UL), 1860 Fairy Tales (FT) and 3,575 Google News articles (GN). The description of how the data sets were created follows. • Urban Legends were harvested from the snopes.com website. • While nearly 5,000 urban legends were collected and discussed on the website, we only looked at those that were reported along with a text example, usually circulated via e-mail2. We then kept only these text examples if they were at least thirty tokens long. • News articles were selected from a corpus of approximately 400,000 GoogleNews articles from 2009-2012.

sections.heading: 6. Classification Experiments
sections.text: The aim of our experiments is to understand to what extent it is possible to assign a text to one of the aforementioned classes < < 01 = 33 functions together, using only the prototypical features discussed above, and whether there is a subset of features that stands out among the others in this classification task. For each combination of features, we conducted an experiment with a tenfold cross-validation on the dataset. We also standardized all characteristics by z-score. We randomly calculated all characteristics to balance the majority class, i.e. 50% of positive examples and 50% of negative examples; these accounts for a random baseline of 0.5. We also standardized all characteristics by z-score. The experiments were conducted using SVM (Vapnik, 1995), in particular libSVM (Chang & Lin, 2011) under its default settings. sections.heading: 7. Discussion
sections.text: While UL and GN are distinguished by a skilful blend of all prototypical features combined, with none of the features showing clear superiority over the others, UL and FT readability (READ) and affect (AFF) play an important role. As the summary in Table 9 shows, ALL features together have the highest average value of F1, but READ is the most powerful subset of features in all experiments, followed by AFF, NER and TIMEX, which perform reasonably well. Generally, these experiments have demonstrated the quality of our features in distinguishing UL from FT and GN within a machine learning framework and confirm the results obtained from the part of the quantitative analysis. sections.heading: 9. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a study of urban legends, a genre of modern folklore consisting of stories about some rare and extraordinary events that are plausible enough to be believed; we argued that urban legends are a form of "sticky" deceptive text characterized by a tension between believable and unbelievable; to be credible, they should resemble a news article and be unbelievable as a fairy tale at the same time; we focused in particular on the idea that ULs should imitate the details of news (who, where, when) in order to be credible, and at the same time emotional and readable as a fairy tale in order to be memorable and memorable; using NLP tools, we presented a quantitative analysis of these simple but effective features and provided some machine learning experiments that showed that it is possible to recognize an urban legend by precisely these prototypical characteristics, while in the future we wanted to examine other banal aspects of urban analogies such as Louis & Pennekova's 2001, for example;

For example the sewer alligator, that originally “appeared” in New York City (Coleman, 1979), also appeared in different cities to suit regional variations.

In (Heath & Heath, 2007), the authors discuss the idea of “stickiness” popularized by the book “The Tipping Point” (Gladwell, 2000), seeking to explain what makes an idea or concept memorable or interesting.
For example, the idea that urban legends derive much of their credibility from details concerning the location where the situation took place, is presented in (Brunvand, 1981).
